lines.text: Enter Second Merchant, ANGELO, and an Officer

lines.speaker: second merchant
lines.text: You know since Pentecost the sum is due, And since I have not much importuned you Nor now I had not, but that I am bound To Persia, and want guilders for my voyage: Therefore make present satisfaction, Or Ill attach you by this officer.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Even just the sum that I do owe to you Is growing to me by Antipholus, And in the instant that I met with you He had of me a chain: at five oclock I shall receive the money for the same. Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house, I will discharge my bond and thank you too.
Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus from the courtezans

lines.speaker: officer
lines.text: That labour may you save: see where he comes. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: While I go to the goldsmiths house, go thou And buy a ropes end: that will I bestow Among my wife and her confederates, For locking me out of my doors by day. But, soft! I see the goldsmith. Get thee gone Buy thou a rope and bring it home to me.

lines.speaker: dromio of ephesus
lines.text: I buy a thousand pound a year: I buy a rope. ANTIPHOLUS
Exit

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: A man is well holp up that trusts to you: I promised your presence and the chain But neither chain nor goldsmith came to me. Belike you thought our love would last too long, If it were chaind together, and therefore came not.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Saving your merry humour, heres the note How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat, The fineness of the gold and chargeful fashion. Which doth amount to three odd ducats more Than I stand debted to this gentleman: I pray you, see him presently discharged, For he is bound to sea and stays but for it. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: I am not furnishd with the present money Besides, I have some business in the town. Good signior, take the stranger to my house And with you take the chain and bid my wife Disburse the sum on the receipt thereof: Perchance I will be there as soon as you.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Then you will bring the chain to her yourself ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: No bear it with you, lest I come not time enough.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Well, sir, I will. Have you the chain about you ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: An if I have not, sir, I hope you have Or else you may return without your money.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Nay, come, I pray you, sir, give me the chain: Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman, And I, to blame, have held him here too long. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: Good Lord! you use this dalliance to excuse Your breach of promise to the Porpentine. I should have chid you for not bringing it, But, like a shrew, you first begin to brawl.

lines.speaker: second merchant
lines.text: The hour steals on I pray you, sir, dispatch.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: You hear how he importunes methe chain! ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: Why, give it to my wife and fetch your money.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Come, come, you know I gave it you even now. Either send the chain or send me by some token. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: Fie, now you run this humour out of breath, wheres the chain I pray you, let me see it.

lines.speaker: second merchant
lines.text: My business cannot brook this dalliance. Good sir, say whether youll answer me or no: If not, Ill leave him to the officer. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: I answer you! what should I answer you

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: The money that you owe me for the chain. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: I owe you none till I receive the chain.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: You know I gave it you half an hour since. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: You gave me none: you wrong me much to say so.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: You wrong me more, sir, in denying it: Consider how it stands upon my credit.

lines.speaker: second merchant
lines.text: Well, officer, arrest him at my suit.

lines.speaker: officer
lines.text: I do and charge you in the dukes name to obey me.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: This touches me in reputation. Either consent to pay this sum for me Or I attach you by this officer. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: Consent to pay thee that I never had! Arrest me, foolish fellow, if thou darest.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Here is thy fee arrest him, officer, I would not spare my brother in this case, If he should scorn me so apparently.

lines.speaker: officer
lines.text: I do arrest you, sir: you hear the suit. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: I do obey thee till I give thee bail. But, sirrah, you shall buy this sport as dear As all the metal in your shop will answer.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Sir, sir, I will have law in Ephesus, To your notorious shame I doubt it not.
Enter DROMIO of Syracuse, from the bay

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Master, there is a bark of Epidamnum That stays but till her owner comes aboard, And then, sir, she bears away. Our fraughtage, sir, I have conveyd aboard and I have bought The oil, the balsamum and aquavitae. The ship is in her trim the merry wind Blows fair from land: they stay for nought at all But for their owner, master, and yourself. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: How now! a madman! Why, thou peevish sheep, What ship of Epidamnum stays for me

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: A ship you sent me to, to hire waftage. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: Thou drunken slave, I sent thee for a rope And told thee to what purpose and what end.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: You sent me for a ropes end as soon: You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of ephesus
lines.text: I will debate this matter at more leisure And teach your ears to list me with more heed. To Adriana, villain, hie thee straight: Give her this key, and tell her, in the desk Thats coverd oer with Turkish tapestry, There is a purse of ducats let her send it: Tell her I am arrested in the street And that shall bail me hie thee, slave, be gone! On, officer, to prison till it come.
Exeunt Second Merchant, Angelo, Officer, and Antipholus of Ephesus

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: To Adriana! that is where we dined, Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband: She is too big, I hope, for me to compass. Thither I must, although against my will, For servants must their masters minds fulfil.
Exit
